title: 107_hr4980
content: The "Citizen Involvement in Campaigns Act of 2002" allows for a tax credit for certain political contributions under section 25C of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The tax credit for political contributions under section 25C of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows individuals to claim a credit for all political contributions made during the taxable year, with a maximum limit of $200 ($400 for joint returns). Contributions must be verified as prescribed by the Secretary to qualify for the credit. The tax credit for political contributions under section 25C of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows individuals to claim a credit for all political contributions made during the taxable year, with a maximum limit of $200 ($400 for joint returns). Contributions must be verified as prescribed by the Secretary to qualify for the credit. The term 'candidate' refers to an individual running for Federal elective public office who publicly announces their candidacy and meets the qualifications prescribed by law. The term 'national political party' is defined as a party presenting candidates for President and Vice President on the official election ballot of ten or more States during a taxable year, or a party that met these qualifications in the last preceding election. No deduction allowed for amounts used to determine the credit for President and Vice President candidates. The text introduces a new credit for political contributions under section 25C and specifies that the amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31 of the year the Act is enacted. SEC. 223 introduces a deduction for political contributions in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. In the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, a deduction is introduced for qualified political contributions made by individuals, limited to $600 ($1200 for joint returns). This deduction is allowed regardless of whether the taxpayer itemizes other deductions. The table of sections for part VII of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by adding new items. The amendments regarding political contributions and cross references will apply to taxable years starting after December 31 of the year in which this Act is enacted.
